metadata.title: "Are Experts Better Than Algorithms?" | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: The spread of algorithms (artificial intelligence, machine learning) gives rise to a valid question―now asked often: Are expert decisions better than the predictions made by algorithms? This article examines the roles played by cognitive bias and cognitive overload to provide the answers.

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: “Why Cancer-Spotting AI Needs To Be Handled With Care”

all_paragraphs: “Brain: an apparatus with which we think we think.”―Ambrose Bierce
“I was gratified to be able to answer promptly, and I did. I said I didn’t know.”―Mark Twain
“Your assumptions are your windows on the world. Scrub them off every once in a while, or the light won’t come in.”―Isaac Asimov

The spread of algorithms (artificial intelligence, machine learning) gives rise to a valid question: Are expert decisions better than the predictions made by algorithms? It is a question portending an existential crisis for human know-how and actions, as it is being asked often.

For example, a recent report in The Verge was titled: “Why Cancer-Spotting AI Needs To Be Handled With Care” (by James Vincent, January 27, 2020). From the report: “But for many in health care, what studies like these demonstrate is not just the promise of AI, but also its potential threat. They say that for all of the obvious abilities of algorithms to crunch data, the subtle, judgment-based skills of nurses and doctors are not so easily digitized.”
But such views ignore evidence that suggests otherwise. There are two key factors―(1) cognitive bias and (2) cognitive overload―that play a role.
To answer this question (experts vs. algorithms), let us first look at the role played by cognitive bias.

Daniel Kahneman, the psychologist and behavior economics pioneer, won the Nobel Prize for Economics in 2002 “for having integrated insights from psychological research into economic science, especially concerning human judgment and decision-making under uncertainty.” His collaboration with economist Amos Tversky is well known―a partnership that resulted in a number of foundational results in behavioral economics, particularly the development of “Prospect Theory” in the 1970s.

Prospect Theory was an important update―a behavioral framing of the loss and gain asymmetry in human estimates―to classical utility theory, the foundation of modern economic theories, first offered by Daniel Bernoulli in 1738 as the famous resolution of the “St. Petersburg Paradox” and woven into its modern form―expected utility theory―by John Von Neumann and Oskar Morgenstern in the 1940s using the axioms of rational choice. (While Von Neumann and Morgenstern framed modern utility theory using the axioms of rational choice, Bernoulli in 1738 set up the utility construct as “moral expectation” as opposed to mathematical expectation, highlighting his view of utility as a subjective construct rather than a mathematical one. This was the key point of his argument: that a pauper’s moral expectation is different from that of a rich person’s―making Daniel Bernoulli the true behavioral economics pioneer.)

Tversky would almost certainly have shared the Nobel Prize with Kahneman but for his untimely death in 1996 (Kahneman shared the Nobel award with economist Vernon Smith, known for his pioneering role in Experimental Economics).

It was in graduate school that I first encountered their classic paper “Judgment Under Uncertainty: Heuristics and Biases” (Tversky and Kahneman, 1974) and was immediately drawn into the fascinating world of judgment under uncertainty, the role of heuristics in decision making and the systematic biases the occur as a result. In this classic paper, Tversky and Kahneman cluster these biases that arise into three key heuristics: representativeness (the probable degree to which an object represents a particular type); availability (the subjective assessment of the probability of an event based on instances or occurrences that come to one’s mind); and adjustment from an anchor (the subjective estimates made starting from an initial value and adjusted to yield the final answer, with these adjustments typically proving insufficient).

In his wonderful book “Thinking, Fast and Slow” (2011), Daniel Kahneman explains the notions taking root in psychology that human thinking is a mix of two mental systems: a fast, intuitive, automatic, almost involuntary process (System 1) coupled with a slow, deliberative, conscious one that requires concentration and effort (System 2). The interaction of these two systems enables our thoughts and actions. (Note the comma after Thinking in the book title highlighting Fast and Slow.)

Kahneman looks into the question of experts vs. algorithms in the section “Intuition vs. Formulas.” He highlights the interesting findings of clinical psychologist Paul Meehl regarding expert intuition and the use of formulas for guidance. Meehl’s findings revealed that simple algorithms (statistical predictions) outperformed or tied experts (clinical judgment) in almost all the domains tested. As Kahneman notes, the ease of implementation makes even a tie a win for algorithms. These results (“the Meehl patterns”) understandably shocked the clinical establishment then as the advances of AI continue to do so now.

It is the famous Apgar Score highlighted by Kahneman that makes the point clearly. “In 1953, Virginia Apgar, M.D. published her proposal for a new method of evaluation of the newborn infant. The avowed purpose of this paper was to establish a simple and clear classification of newborn infants which can be used to compare the results of obstetric practices, types of maternal pain relief and the results of resuscitation. Having considered several objective signs pertaining to the condition of the infant at birth she selected five that could be evaluated and taught to the delivery room personnel without difficulty. These signs were heart rate, respiratory effort, reflex irritability, muscle tone and color. Sixty seconds after the complete birth of the baby a rating of zero, one or two was given to each sign, depending on whether it was absent or present.” (Source: “The Apgar Score Has Survived The Test of Time,” Dr. Finster & Dr. Wood, 2005)

In short, this simple score (0–10) obtained 1 min after birth by the delivery room personnel provided (and still continues to provide) the prognosis for the newborn (excellent if 8–10, fair if 3–7, poor if 0–2). Importantly, Dr. Apgar selected five objective signs “that could be evaluated and taught to the delivery room personnel without difficulty”―that is, it could be easily understood by non-experts. The Apgar scoring had a tremendous impact in reducing infant mortality. According to Dr. Richard Smiley of the New York-Presbyterian/Columbia University Medical Center: “The score gave physicians and nurses a requirement to look at the newborn in an organized method and it’s helped prevent the death of countless babies. Once physicians and nurses had to assign a score, it created an imperative to act to improve the score. It was essentially the birth of clinical neonatology.” (Source: New York-Presbyterian Health Matters: “It Happened Here: The Apgar Score”)
The pioneering Dr. Virginia Apgar was the first female physician to hold a full professorship at Columbia’s College of Physicians and Surgeons.

Kahneman’s research into this question of Intuition vs. Formulas suggests that “whenever we can replace human judgement by a formula, we should at least consider it.” Biases (hubris, overconfidence, etc) get in the way of objectivity. Irrelevant context or the saliency bias affects consistency. Algorithms have the potential to offer objective and consistent judgments in situations with poor predictability. Using the frame provided by Kahneman, it is easy to see that employing System 1 thinking (fast intuition) in areas where System 2 thinking (slow deliberation) is called for can produce these situations. Recognizing these patterns can help planners in different domains put together strategies (like Dr. Apgar did) to keep the assessments objective and consistent where the situation (such as speedily assessing the newborn a min after birth) seems to demand intuition.

Let us now look at the question of experts vs. algorithms by examining the role played by cognitive overload. Cognitive overload is a consequence of the growth of complexity and the reality of human limits.

Dr. Atul Gawande rose to prominence with his essays on healthcare in The New Yorker magazine. His first book “Complications: A Surgeon’s Notes on an Imperfect Science” (2002), a collection of essays written during his residency at Brigham and Women’s Hospital won him a National Book Award. “The essays that comprise Complications (many of which originally appeared as articles in The New Yorker) are divided into three sections―’Fallibility,’ ‘Mystery,’ and ‘Uncertainty’―each dealing with a different sort of imperfection or difficulty in medical practice. Gawande thus explores the many ways that medicine can fall short of expectations. Humans err, despite their best efforts. Scientific knowledge remains incomplete, leaving many questions unanswered and unanswerable. And some situations are simply ambiguous, calling for the exercise of judgment in the face of maddeningly incomplete information, often with no good solution available.” (Source: “Like a Surgeon,” Steven Lubet, May 2003, Cornell Law Review)

Human fallibility, what we do not know and making judgments with incomplete information are part of any situation. When these come together in a situation where timing matters (e.g. the 1 min after birth for newborns or the 90 min after arrival for cardiac attacks) and complexity is ever present, the recourse to algorithms (and formulas) may be necessary.

In 2009, Gawande came out with “The Checklist Manifesto: How To Get Things Right,”where he looks at how to take the hard won but unmanageable know-how accumulated by “highly trained, highly skilled and hardworking people” and eliminate common and persistent failures that are avoidable by prescribing a strategy for “overcoming failure, one that builds on experience and takes advantage of the knowledge people have but somehow also makes up for our inevitable human inadequacies”―a checklist!

Echoing the insights of Apgar, Gawande suggests that: “Checklists seem to provide protection against such failures. They remind us of the minimum necessary steps and make them explicit. They not only offer the possibility of verification but also instill a kind of discipline of higher performance.” As an example, Gawande discusses how the checklist devised by critical care specialist Peter Provonost at Johns Hopkins Hospital to tackle the problem of central line infections in the ICU showed a dramatic drop in such infections (driving it down to almost zero) over a two year period. The other example of an Austrian child’s miraculous recovery after sliding into an icy pond shows how the rapid and coordinated sophistication of modern medicine can pull off such miracles. The Checklist Manifesto has a lot of such examples and is a fascinating read.

Checklists or formulas or algorithms can provide an objective and consistent path to eliminate avoidable failures by focusing on the minimum necessary in a time-sensitive situation where the ever-growing complexity and human fallibility (and human limits) can combine adversely. There are potentially areas where this algorithmic approach may not work that well (at least currently) but it is important to acknowledge all the areas where this will work well.

This view of algorithms goes against the current wisdom of experts and pundits. But theory and experience provide ample support for this view, showing why it is important to at least consider the role of algorithms in planning complex operations and pooling of expertise for complex projects.
Why do simple algorithms do the trick so well in such situations? By distilling the signal from the noise that surrounds it.

Treating cognitive bias as experts filtering information inefficiently or adversely and cognitive overload as human incapacity or limits when faced with a barrage of information, algorithms can overcome such barriers for decisions to be objective and consistent.

This essay examines only the relative merits of experts vs. algorithms under typical conditions of uncertainty and complexity, eschewing the larger question of the ethical, societal and economic impact of introducing algorithms. The lessons of the Industrial Revolution and the insights of Karl Marx about the trajectory of automation expounded in his famous work Capital (Das Kapital) are relevant for that discussion. But I will save that for another day.
“The instrument of labour, when it takes the form of a machine, immediately becomes a competitor of the workman himself.”―Karl Marx, Capital Volume One
Look forward to your questions, comments and feedback.
Suresh Babu | February 6, 2020 | San Francisco Bay Area
My interests on the AI front:
Advisor + Entrepreneur + Writer > AI + Impact
